title: a or an before H?
value: Use “an” before a silent H as with an heir, an hour, an honest politician, an honorary consul. Use “a” before an aspirated H as with a hero, a hotel, a historian.

title: Etcetera
value: Write as etc without a dot at the end. It should be written as “etc.” when at the end of a sentence.

title: e.g. and i.e.
value: Use this form and always follow with a comma.

title: Oxford comma
value: Generally, we don’t like oxford commas unless essential for clarity.

title: Quoting Speech
value: All speech should be in double quotes.

title: Punctuation within quotes
value: The period and the comma always go within the quotation marks. The dash, semicolon, colon, question mark and exclamation point go within the quotation marks when they apply to the quoted matter only. They go outside when they apply to the whole sentence.

title: A word in another language
value: Use italics if not commonly used.

title: Dash
value: Use an EM dash whether for parentheses or to separate groups of words. Don’t use a hyphen. Use an EN dash to separate dates as in 1999–2001 or simply write as 1999 to 2001.

title: Ellipsis
value: If someone trails off while speaking use “...”

title: Round brackets
value: Used as parentheses only when the sentence doesn’t make grammatical sense without.
